A uniform rope of length 10 meters and a mass of 5 kg is hanging vertically from a support. Initially, the rope is in a state of rest. At time t=0, a wave pulse is generated at the upper end of the rope. The wave travels downwards with a speed of 5 m/s. If the tension in the rope is 800 N, find the displacement and velocity of each particle of the rope at t = 2 seconds.

Since the wave travels downwards with a speed of 5 m/s, after 2 seconds, the wave pulse will have traveled a distance of:

Distance = Speed × Time
Distance = 5 m/s × 2 s = 10 meters

Since the rope is 10 meters long, the wave pulse will have reached the bottom of the rope at t = 2 seconds.

Now, let's consider the displacement and velocity of each particle of the rope. Since the wave pulse has reached the bottom of the rope, the particles at the top of the rope have already been affected by the wave and are now oscillating. The particles at the bottom of the rope are just starting to be affected by the wave pulse.

The displacement of the particles will depend on the shape of the wave pulse, which is not provided in the problem. However, we can still discuss the general behavior of the particles.

The particles at the top of the rope will have a displacement from their equilibrium position due to the wave pulse. The exact displacement will depend on the shape of the wave pulse and the time elapsed since the wave pulse affected that particular particle.

The particles at the bottom of the rope will have just started to be affected by the wave pulse at t = 2 seconds. Their displacement will be small initially and will increase as the wave pulse continues to affect them.

The velocity of each particle will also depend on the shape of the wave pulse and the time elapsed since the wave pulse affected that particular particle. The particles at the top of the rope will have a non-zero velocity due to the wave pulse, while the particles at the bottom of the rope will have just started to gain velocity as they are affected by the wave pulse.

In summary, without knowing the shape of the wave pulse, we cannot provide exact values for the displacement and velocity of each particle of the rope at t = 2 seconds.
